text:
Hi Tessa, sorry for the lack of messages, it's been a bit chaotic. All good here at the moment thanks, hope the same can be said for you and you're family :slightly_smiling_face:
Ohh, thanks for the link, this is definitely super useful. My University has pretty much gone fully online and this will last until late April, so literally everyone is working from home! Crazy times!

Hey Josh, no worries! This time is a bit crazy and we're here for when and if you need guidance. I will send updates occasionally when I have something useful to share like the podcast, but you're under no obligation to send regular updates.
I'm glad to hear your university is taking the online approach. Things are mostly safe on this end. My only worry is that I'm still working in the office at the moment, but hopefully, by next week we'll be moved out of the office and working from home. Fingers crossed.

On that note, here's another useful one from Escape Studios. There's lots of people writing about this at the moment, so I'll try to filter for the more relevant ones: <https://escapestudiosvfx.com/2020/03/20/sun-loungers-on-the-beach-not-deckchairs-on-the-titanic-14-golden-tips-for-students-working-remotely/>

attachments.title: Sun loungers on the beach, not deckchairs on the titanic: 14 golden tips for students workingÂ remotely
attachments.text: It’s important to have a guiding principle for your ‘home learning’ and to make it work for you. Don’t let your education be defined by COVID-19. This is a new but temporary reality, and we can’t just go into a coma for the coming months. We need to strive to be in the best possible shape for the world afterwards.
attachments.fallback: escapestudiosvfx.com Link: Sun loungers on the beach, not deckchairs on the titanic: 14 golden tips for students working remotely
